text: Whether it’s competition or something else, if someone does sport because they’re motivated to do it rather than as a sense of obligation, they will derive a *lot* more cognitive benefits.
author: pegobry

text: Also the kinds of exercsise that cause the most improvement are (a) activities that are cognitively and not just physically demanding; (b) that the people doing *enjoy* doing, which is evidence for your proposition.
author: pegobry

text: My pet theory is that doing lots of sports works out willpower, which is part of the executive function, also linked to things like planning, decision-making, etc.
author: pegobry

text: The most popular theory is that exercise simply makes the body grow more cells faster, to replace the ones that get burned through physical activity, and there are some spillover effects on the brain.

text: Jean-Marie Le Pen got creampied relatively little, for example, because he was scary, not silly. The whole point was that it was "bon enfant," a French expression I find no English equivalent for—silly in a friendly, non-threatening way.
author: pegobry

text: It was a very delicate thing. It’s obviously not enough to disagree with someone to creampie them. Everyone has to agree that they’re a ridiculous, pretentious person. There was informal social regulation: good creampies would be on the news, and bad ones would be enough.
author: pegobry

text: Someone pressing assault charges after getting creampied—like BHL—or responding with physical violence—also like BHL—would merely confirm that he was the sort of person who deserved a cream pie to the face.
author: pegobry

text: Creampie-ing someone meets the legal definitions of assault and vigilanteeism, and yet obviously it’s ridiculous to consider it as such.
author: pegobry

text: I don’t know why it disappeared. But in a legalistic, process-driven world we should bear in mind those completely informal and extra-legal ways of regulating speech. One of the reasons for the rise in hostility to free speech is because we’ve lost sight of this.
author: pegobry

text: France had a lovely tradition of « entartage ». Citizens would find ways to slam a creampie on the faces of pompous famous individuals, and by and large the system worked well and was self-regulating. (Obviously BHL holds the record as the most creampied person in history.)
author: pegobry

text: It’s possible to see this and also see that it’s medically indisputable that circumcision has more costs than benefits and so you shouldn’t do it to kids if there’s no religious motive. There’s no contradiction! There’s even harmony!
author: pegobry

text: E. We really should spend more time training ourselves to hold more than one idea in our head at the same time. I find incredible beauty and power in the Jewish rite of circumcision, of symbolizing the belonging to the covenant through a mark on one’s intimate flesh.
author: pegobry

text: D. So we should all calm down and agree that, while not, like, child abuse or cancer, male circumcision is plainly unjustified, unless there is a compelling motive, which religious belief clearly is, because religious liberty is an intrinsic good necessary for human flourishing.
author: pegobry

text: And intactivists themselves, because they’re a small minority, because it’s a sensitive subject, because it adds insult to injury when the US medical establishment asserts transparently false claims as facts, tend to be emotional and make overblown claims.
author: pegobry

text:

It doesn’t help when Northern European countries and sundry ideologues want to ban all circumcision, which is clearly atrocious.

author: pegobry

text: You can really trace the decline of style in French literature to the decline of Latin.
author: pegobry

text: And of course, the idea that you shouldn’t just "do" things, but do them in style, is a fundamental tenet of French culture, and one key aspect of this has now been lost.
author: pegobry

text: ... textbook writers. Latin in general, and especially great writers’ Latin,  implicitly teaches that constructing a sentence isn’t just about conveying meaning, but also at least potentially about doing so in the most elegant way.
author: pegobry

text: Now this implicitly teaches a number of things. First, that there really is a difference between the great writers and everybody else. I lived through the transition from French kids learning Latin from Cesar, Cicero and Ovid to learning it from texts written by well-meaning ...
author: pegobry

text: If there’s the straightforward way to express a thought in Latin takes 8 words, you can bet there’s a less-straightforward way to express the exact same thought in 4.
author: pegobry

text: ... grow up in the sort of family where parents routinely use big complicated words. But (and this is just my opinion), there’s another, subtler aspect, which is that various aspects of Latin make it, notoriously, an extremely pithy language.
author: pegobry

text: Another huge part of this was the teaching of Latin. In part because French is a Romance language and so most big French words are just concatenations of smaller Latin words (like "concatenation"), which means you can figure them out even if you didn’t necessarily...
author: pegobry

text:
Well-meaning American progressives: "You come from the socialist utopia of France, why are you a conservative?"

Me: I hate the poor I guess.
author: pegobry

text: Most of the people I know from my parents’ generation who quit school at 14 to go into the trades have better spelling and grammar than the average student at the top-ranked elite school I attended.
author: pegobry

text: ...The Aristocrats!
author: pegobry

text: French jouenalists typically have master’s degrees in some liberal arts subjects. Of the two young journalists I can remember who could right gud, one was a kid from a traditionalist Catholic family; the others’ parents were famous left-wing Parisian intellectuals.
author: pegobry

text: So now it’s literally impossible to pick up a national daily newspaper that’s spelled correctly. As an editor for French publications, I can’t remember ever getting copy where I didn’t have to collect spelling mistakes.
author: pegobry

text: I lived through the last days of that standard. Because obviously when the #decline happens the answer isn’t to raise the bar and work harder to help people meet it, it’s to drop the standards.
author: pegobry

text: French education is essay-based. Traditionally, one spelling or grammar error was allowed for inattention; at the second one, the teacher would stop reading and give you an F. (Often they would ceremonially cross over everything with a red pen.)
author: pegobry

text: This *obviously* gave a *huuuuuge* leg up to bourgeois kids, who get French culture in their social environment.
author: pegobry

text: When France’s radical left-wing unions took over the Education Ministry in ‘68, they stopped teaching kids spelling or grammar because these things are bourgeois and elitist (I wish I were joking).
author: pegobry

text: (Not that classes at Sciences Po are hard, as far as these things go. #IntraFrenchEliteTrolling )
author: pegobry

text: In part they had no choice because France’s high schools are such a disaster. If you’re in a below-median French high school today, you probably cannot write a grammatical sentence, let alone follow a college seminar on 20th century history or whatever.
author: pegobry

text: This is such an obvious and obviously superior system that you have to wonder why they’re not doing it. Every top school should have a network of feeder charter high schools.
author: pegobry

text: (b) and they were explicit about this, giving a leg up to poor rural whites as well as non-whites from the Banlieues.
author: pegobry

text: This addressed some of the most pointed (legit) criticisms of US-style affirmative action, namely (a) preparing under-privileged kids for success in an elite institution instead of just giving them a ticket;
author: pegobry

text: (Meanwhile all other candidates apply via a sit-down exam that I wouldn’t really describe as "transparent" but certainly is a model of transparency compared to the kabuki of Ivy League admissions.)
author: pegobry

text: This does not guarantee admission, and students who do not follow the program are dropped. But those who did got to apply on a special track and Sciences Po established an explicit quota of students from this track.
author: pegobry

text: Instead of giving people extra points or whatever, they partnered with high schools in France’s poorest ghettos, asked teachers to identify high-potential sophomores, and engaged them in a multi-year coaching process.
author: pegobry

text: When Sciences Po, an elite French college, implemented affirmative action, they decided to do it not race-based or class-based, but *regional-based*.
author: pegobry

text: Given the current debates about affirmative action and meritocracy, I just want to point to a French experiment that seems to be working pretty successfully.
author: pegobry

text: But the progressive *wants* to lose them.
author: pegobry

text: It’s actually striking how often he responds to real or perceived attacks by lashing out. I remember an interview where a (Russian, pliant) interviewer asked him how he felt about having been entrusted with launch codes to a nuclear arsenal.

text: For "science" grads, I’ve been surprised at how innumerate most doctors I know are. If a doctor and a non-doctor who knows what p-values are read the relevant literature in a medical field, the latter will actually understand the science better.

text: Et je pense qu’on ne peut pas nier que ça a beaucoup accru les tensions. Notamment l’interdiction du mariage interethnique. (La plus grosse rébellion plébéienne à Rome a eu lieu lorsque les patriciens ont voulu interdire le mariage entre patriciens & plébéiens.)
author: pegobry

text: Les ethnies préexistaient, mais les Belges ont rigidifié les catégories. Comme à Rome de grandes familles plébéiennes étaient aussi riches et presque aussi « installées » que des gens patriciennes, il y avait une « zone grise » entre les deux groupes, bien que réels.
author: pegobry

text:
Me fait penser aux débats intra-cathos sur la sexualité, tiens. 
T'es consacré/marié ? Tu ne peux pas comprendre ce que vivent les gens en "situation irrégulière", donc tais-toi. 
T'es toi-même en "situation irrégulière" ? T'es hypocrite, donc tais-toi.

text: Les attaques perso sur la pseudo-hypocrisie, les gens apparemment trouvent ça irrésistible, ça me consterne. "Leonardo Di Caprio se rend en jet privé à un sommet environnemental! LOLPTDR!" Vraiment, la pensée atteint des sommets.

text: Donc mon opinion sur le Grand Remplacement c’est que je n’ai pas d’opinion parce que je ne comprends pas de quoi on parle.
author: pegobry

text: C’est beaucoup moins une théorie du complot que, par exemple, la thèse de l’obsolescence programmée, dont le Parlement de la République française a fait un délit.
author: pegobry

text: C’est un outil d’analyse qui comme tout outil d’analyse a ses limites mais peut parfois (comme le savent si bien les marxistes) peut être très révélateur. Et il me semble que c’est comme ça que Camus l’utilise—à tort ou à raison, mais il ne s’agit pas d’une théorie du complot.
author: pegobry

text: J’attends avec impatience qu’on désigne le féminisme comme théorie du complot.
author: pegobry

text: Non, elles parlent d’un mélange d’idéologie et d’intérêts de classe qui font qu’un groupe dominant se comporte souvent, vu comme un aggrégat, *comme si* il était coordonné, bien que personne ne prétend ou pense qu’il l’est.
author: pegobry

text: Analogie : quand les féministes parlent du « Patriarcat », elles ne pensent pas qu’il y a un Club Secret des Mâles (blancs) qui se réunissent toutes les semaines pour fumer des cigares et dire « Bon, qu’est-ce qu’on va faire pour opprimer les femmes ? »
author: pegobry

text: Alors certes il parle du « remplacisme » et des « remplacistes » mais pour lui il s’agit tout simplement d’une idéologie.
author: pegobry

text: Ce qui me perturbe encore plus c’est l’idée qu’il s’agit d’une « théorie du complot ». Je ne suis pas expert en renaudcamusologie mais je n’ai rien vu qui indique une théorie du complot.
author: pegobry

text: En tous les cas c’est une question empirique. Et une thèse empirique peut être fausse, mais pas condamnable moralement.
author: pegobry

text: ... que, par exemple, dire que les vaccins provoquent l’autisme, que la terre est plate...ou que le glyphosate est dangereux.  C’est peut-être faux, mais pas en soi absurde.
author: pegobry

text: Ça ne veut pas dire que Camus & co ont raison. Mais il ne font que prolonger des courbes (peu ou prou) existantes, comme les écolos et les analystes financiers qui créent les bulles spéculatives. ;) Autrement dit, parler de Grand Remplacement, ce n’est pas aussi dingue ...
author: pegobry

text: (Et si la natalité du groupe B n’est pas suffisante pour assurer le renouvellement des générations, il disparaîtra à terme.)
author: pegobry

text: Ensuite, il me semble que c’est tout simplement un fait que la population immigrée et d’origine immigrée augmente depuis ~40 ans. Par définition si un groupe A augmente par rapport à un groupe B indéfiniment, il deviendra plus nombreux.
author: pegobry

text: S’il s’agit de savoir si des populations allogènes sont en passe de devenir majoritaires, il me semble que c’est une question empirique, difficilement résolvable dans la mesure où les statistiques ethniques sont illégales.
author: pegobry

text: J’avoue que je n’ai pas de point de vue sur le Grand Remplacement, parce que je n’ai aucune idée de quoi on parle.

text: And, of course, more generally, it’s a tendency to promote an "A people" theory and a "B people" theory depending on whether you perceive that to be in your political interest.
author: pegobry

text: But honestly, it seems to be the representative view that, pretty much, all jihadists are "A people" and all "far-right" mass-killers are "B people." (And far-left mass killers like the Congressional baseball shooter don’t exist).
author: pegobry

text: My sense is that both "A people" and "B people" exist. I don’t get a good sense of what the proportions are, or what goes on with "B people."
author: pegobry

text:
I see basically two models of how people become mass killers:
A. There’s an underlying insanity, and whatever beliefs they espouse are really just a pretext. 
B. Some ppl have a pre-existing insanity, but it is exposure to some kinds of rhetoric that pushes them over the edge.
author: pegobry

text: Whether, and to what extent, and by what mechanisms, rhetoric leads people to become violent, is a fascinating and important topic. Which is precisely why we should be smart about it.
author: pegobry

text: I’m pretty sure they did. Bonds too. (It was a bond analyst who created an Amazon bankruptcy countdown clock after the bubble burst.)

text: But they raised a bunch more money subsequently throughout the dotcom bubble. I don’t know what the amounts were but it’d be interesting to see what they were relative to "internet GDP" then vs today.
author: pegobry

text: I have serious reservations about Uber (et al)’s unit economics. But I don’t know much about the delivery space, which is why I’d love to read a good business model analysis, rather than generalities about unprofitable companies raising money.
author: pegobry

text: Right, hence my point about risks. I think companies that rely on outsourced gig economy workers face a regulatory backlash.

text: 8. A new intellectual movement within academia that very seriously argues and very seriously believes that speech is or can be a form of violence. (Yes, fringe, currently, but ideas metastasize from the academic fringe to the mainstream all the time, as arguably this one is.)
author: pegobry

text: So there’s something going on beyond the normal and healthy give-and-take about defining the borders of acceptable speech.
author: pegobry

text: (And then there’s the Peter Thiel thesis that we’ve got the great stagnation because we’ve enforced this sort of stultifying social conformity on society which cashes out in all these weird ways like economic bubbles, tracked education, etc.)
author: pegobry

text: See e.g. this. There are large groups of people who spend their time harassing companies that host (not publish, host!) controversial content. This seems new.
author: pegobry

text: But when Bret Weinstein, (a) not a public figure and (b) an academic so someone we do expect to have a "protected status" loses his job for speaking out against (as he saw it) racial discrimination, we’re talking about something else.
author: pegobry

text: The example of Ilhan Omar is kind of weird because if there’s one profession where it’s totally acceptable to get in trouble, up to potentially losing your job, for saying things people don’t like, it’s elected official—it’s just baked into the gig.
author: pegobry

text:
4. Outrage archaeologists. 
5. Social media mobs.  
6. Increasing economic and not just social penalties. 
7. Regular people without a public profile being turned into two minutes hate subjects, not just public figures.
author: pegobry

text:
BUT... here are some things that aren’t just that:
1. General hyperpartisanship and rancor. 
2. Institutions supposedly designed to be neutral arbiters of those disputes being partisan and growing more so every day. 
3. Justified loss of prestige by elite institutions.
author: pegobry

text: Damon makes a very valid point, which is that we’ll always have boundaries on acceptable speech, and society needs to have healthy debate about where those boundaries should be. That’s always been true, always will be.
author: pegobry

text: Et bravo à @quatremer de ne pas hésiter d’enquêter sur une institution qu’il défend habituellement.
